gemini_prompt:
1. Analysis and Tag Assignment:  
   • Analyze the provided chapter text to determine the distinct voices present.

2. CRITICAL - Character Name Extraction:
   • Before tagging, identify every character who speaks or is described in this text.
   • For EACH character, extract ONLY their actual first and last name—ignore all titles, ranks, and descriptors.
   • Example: "Commander John Doe" → extract as "John Doe" → tag as [john-doe-male]
   • Example: "Dr. Sarah Chen" → extract as "Sarah Chen" → tag as [sarah-chen-female]
   • If a character is referred to by multiple names or titles in the text, they are still ONE character with ONE tag based on their actual name.

3. Reprinting the Chapter with Granular Gendered Tagging:
   • Reprint the chapter exactly as provided, inserting the corresponding gendered tag immediately before and after each text segment being spoken by a unique speaker.
   • Granularity Requirement:
     • Every narrative block is wrapped with appropriate tags: [narrator] ... [/narrator]
     • Every dialogue block (text within quotation marks) is wrapped with the appropriate speaker tag.
     • For dialogue that spans multiple sentences or is interleaved with narrative descriptions, split the content into segments and tag each precisely.
     • Ensure that any narrative text interjected between dialogue segments is separately wrapped with [narrator] ... [/narrator].
     • Each narrative text is on its own line.

4. Tag Format Requirements - ABSOLUTE RULES:
   • Tag format MUST ALWAYS be: [firstname-lastname-gender]...[/firstname-lastname-gender]
   • ONLY use the character's actual first name and last name. Nothing else.
   • NEVER include titles, ranks, professions, or any descriptors in the tag.
   • All letters in tags must be lowercase.
   • Names are separated by single hyphens. Gender goes at the end.
   • Examples of CORRECT tags:
     • [john-doe-male]
     • [jane-smith-female]
     • [sarah-chen-female]
   • Examples of WRONG tags (NEVER do these):
     • ❌ [commander-john-doe-male]
     • ❌ [dr-jane-smith-female]
     • ❌ [captain-john-doe-male]
     • ❌ [john-male]
     • ❌ [doe-male]

5. Consistency Rule:
   • When you encounter a character described with a title like "Commander John Doe" or "The captain, Sarah Chen," you must recognize that their actual name is "John Doe" or "Sarah Chen" respectively.
   • Always extract and use only the actual first and last name for the tag, regardless of how they are introduced or described in the text.

6. Customization:
   • Adjust granularity as needed so every change in speaker or return to narrative is clearly indicated.
   • Do not change or alter the actual wording of the chapter text. Only add tags.
   • Always retain chapter headings.
   • Do not insert additional headers or create duplicates.
   • never include the analysis in your output.
   • your only expected output is the converted and tagged dialogue
   • for speakers that are AI or computers, can be identified by a simple [computer-voice]...[/computer-voice] tag.
   • never use [default]...[/default] as a tag, this should always be the narrator.
   • chapter headings will always be tagged with the narrator tag.
